conversations.body_text: Hi Nicolas Guilbert,    Thank you for your quick response and for providing the test package. I just performed the testing and found three issues:    Upon initially connecting our device, it would disconnect and reconnect every few seconds, showing "Connected" again. During this time, each click on the motor channel test would also trigger a disconnection and reconnection. However, after I switched and replugged the device, the issue did not reoccur.    The telemetry command is missing a letter — the correct spelling is telemtry, but in SimHub it was tested as telmtry, missing an "e". This causes the main controller to fail in recognizing the command. Please kindly correct it.    We would like the motor IDs to follow this mapping: throttle = 0, brake = 1, clutch = 2. This matches our software interface and the physical installation order of the motors on the controller.    In response to the two questions you raised:    Each of our devices has a unique HID serial number — they are not fixed across devices. For example, each PlusX controller has a different HID serial number, and this also applies to ProX and ProX Ultra.    The report data I provided under Report ID 1 is for in-game usage. There is also a Report ID 2, which is used when the configuration software starts. If you plan to use data from Report ID 1, please ensure it is properly filtered and read only from Report ID 1.    Additionally, we’ve sold a large number of pedals, and calibration status varies between older and newer models. Before calibration, the value might range from 0% to 50% or more; after calibration, it typically falls between 0% and 2%. Our software also offers dead zone settings between 0% and 15% for both minimum and maximum values — this should be similar to other pedals in the industry. If you're planning to read Report ID 1 to determine pedal actuation and percentage, please take this into account. That said, you might already have a more advanced handling mechanism in place.     ​The HID game data format is as follows: 1 byte Report ID + 2 bytes Throttle + 2 bytes Brake + 2 bytes Clutch.

Hi Nicolas Guilbert,  We have also tested the vibration effect by sending commands via SimHub, and the experience was excellent. However, to ensure system stability and compatibility, the command format still needs to be corrected as mentioned in our previous email. The correct command is: telemtry. In addition, we have shipped a large quantity of products to our overseas warehouses, and global distribution will follow. We would also like to propose updating the name of our pedal devices to: Simsonn Vibration Auxiliary Module (Plus X / Pro X / Pro X Ultra). Thank you for your continued support!     SIMSONN  CEO Devin Email: [support@simsonn.com] Website: [www.simsonn.com] ​

Hi Nicolas Guilbert,     My pedal device indeed has two HID interfaces:    The first interface (shown as mi_00 in the first image) is used to send Report ID 1 for game data. This interface is always active, so you can rely on it to consistently receive gameplay input.    The second interface (shown as mi_01 in the second image) is used for Report ID 2, which is intended for calibration with our configuration software. This interface only transmits or receives data when the software is running — otherwise, it remains idle.

Hi Nicolas Guilbert,  One more thing: use mi_00 for device identification, but telemetry data should be sent via mi_01, as mi_00 is only used for game data output. mi_01 is intended for calibration data required by the software and can also receive telemetry data.

Hi，Nicolas Guilbert，     I just tested the SimHub.9.08.5b4_Simsonn.zip version via the Device panel in SimHub.  Test setup:    PlusX and ProX Ultra controllers;    VAM Pro linear vibration motors;    Vibration tested on all three channels: throttle, brake, and clutch.    Test results:    SimHub successfully and stably connects to the mi_01 interface;    Even after restarting SimHub or reconnecting the controller box, the connection remains stable;    All vibration effects worked as expected with no issues.    Many thanks for your great support and assistance!     Additionally, I have a few more questions I’d like to ask:    While SimHub is running, if I manually unplug our USB device, I can see a device lost error in the SimHub logs. However, if I don’t unplug the device during operation, no error messages appear at all. Does this behavior confirm that our mi_01 interface setup is functioning properly?    You previously mentioned that using the hardware ID to match mi_01 is quite unreliable. Could you kindly provide a few typical examples of when or how it might fail? That would help us better understand and improve our firmware design.    I have completed vibration testing in the SimHub Device tab, and all effects are working correctly. However, I haven’t been able to test telemetry-based effects yet. Am I required to also add our SIMSONN device as an output channel under the ShakeIt Motors section to get telemetry working properly?    Regarding the HID data format on mi_01, I haven’t provided that to you yet. Currently, here is how it's designed: When our SIMSONN Manager software is running, it sends a Report ID 2 + 0x90 command every 5 seconds via mi_01. This triggers our controller to begin sending continuous Report ID 2 packets, which contain both raw (pre-calibration) and calibrated game values. These transmissions last for 30 seconds. If the manager software is closed, the report stream stops after 30 seconds. Meanwhile, mi_00 (Report ID 1) continues sending game data uninterrupted. Based on this, we assume that your “Block effects when not pressed” feature using “Use native controller input” is referencing data from mi_00 — is that correct?    Lastly, I have a more general question:  We plan to implement an automatic game detection and quick launch feature inside SIMSONN Manager. The goal is to detect installed sim racing games without requiring the user to manually select or input the path — and also without us pre-installing hundreds of games. Do you know if there's a common approach (e.g., via registry, Steam/UPlay/EA paths, or system scans) to identify installed racing games and locate their .exe files automatically? Many users struggle to find the correct path themselves, and we’d like to make the process as smooth as possible. If this is outside of your scope, no problem at all!  Thank you again for your great support — we’ll be promoting the SimHub integration actively through our software and website, and we look forward to helping expand the SimHub community together. Hi !

Here are my replies:

1. Yes, every errors are logged, a device unplug has no difference with a
device usb failure, considering the wide number of usb issues (emi, bad usb
cable ...) I have to troubleshoot, all those informations are critical to
know what is happening. So yes when you unplug the device you'll see two
errors, one about the game controller being lost, and one about the hid
interface for motor control being lost.

2. The Hardware id is not necessary deterministic, the descriptor embeds
usage pages and usage which are meant for the identification. When relying
on the mi_0 or mi_1 identification you are relying on the windows
identification order and/or the descriptor interfaces declaration order. If
you want to add later a keyboard interface or another custom interface,
those could suddenly get reordered or renumbered. If the interface is
identified by a specific usage page and usage number, then no matter what
can be done on the device descriptors the interface can still be identified.

3. That's really weird I'll check on Monday, this specific interface has
still not been deployed for many devices, and I might have missed something
when I adapted it to work with your pedals. The shake it interface is
unrelated now, everything you need is bundled inside the "device
interface". Can I ask which game and did you see it as connected inside
Simhub (no UDP conflicts for instance)

4. Good point, since it's two interfaces I would need to open both. I was
originally expecting it to be only one interface, and I didn't challenged
it again when you told me there were two. I need to adapt it. For the same
reason as #1 if you can provide the exact usage page and usage id that
would allow me to identify it in a future proof way without relying on
windows numbering.


Concerning the game detection, it’s something I’ve built the hard way,
going through Steam and other libraries with added heuristics over time.
It’s become a part of SimHub’s core value, so it’s not something I can
really share outside the project.
Thanks for your understanding!


Best regards,
Nicolas Guilbert
